lesson.name: Lesson 5.1 Teacher Guide: Properties of Exponents

page.title: 5.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

This opening lesson introduces students to performing operations on expressions with exponents. They will start by representing exponents as repeated multiplication to reinforce the meaning of exponents. Students will use the Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents when multiplying and dividing expressions with exponents.

Students will learn to simplify expressions that have a zero as an exponent, in addition to expressions with negative exponents. They will use the Power Property for Exponents to simplify expressions that raise a power to a power. Students will also use the Product to a Power Property and Quotient to a Power Property to simplify expressions in which the entire product or quotient is raised to a power.

In subsequent lessons, students will continue using exponents to explore exponential growth and decay.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Simplify expressions by adding the exponents of bases that are being multiplied and subtracting the exponents of bases that are being divided.
  • Simplify any base with an exponent of zero to a value of \(1\).
  • Simplify expressions with negative exponents by taking the reciprocal of the base and changing the sign of the exponent.
  • Distribute an exponent through a multiplication or division expression using relevant exponent properties.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Simplify expressions using different properties for exponents.
  • Simplify expressions containing exponents of zero.
  • Use the definition of a negative exponent to simplify expressions.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A11(B) simplify numeric and algebraic expressions using the laws of exponents, including integral and rational exponents.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 5.1.1: Understanding Exponents
  • 5.1.2: Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents
    • 5.1.2: Self Check
    • 5.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 5.1.3: Using Zero Exponent Property and Negative Exponents
    • 5.1.3: Self Check
    • 5.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 5.1.4: Using Power Properties for Exponents
    • 5.1.4: Self Check
    • 5.1.4: Additional Resources
  • 5.1.5: Simplifying Exponents

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 5.1.6: Practice.

Required Materials

  • paper and pencil

Required Preparation

  • none

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • expression
  • Power Property
  • Product to a Power Property
  • Product Property
  • Properties of Negative Exponents
  • Quotient Property
  • Quotient to a Negative Power Property
  • Quotient to a Power Property
  • Zero Exponent Property

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their grit.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • The Paramecium Principle
  • Step by Step

You can find other tips located here in the Grit Playbook from Character Lab.

page.title: 5.1.1: Understanding Exponents
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)


This warm-up reviews and reinforces the idea that exponents can be represented equivalently as repeated multiplication. Students will translate constant and variable bases with exponents to multiplication expressions.

Launch

Display the introduction and the example expressions. Ask the class to explain the relationship between exponents and repeated multiplication. Display the exponential expressions. Give students quiet think-time for each problem and ask them to give a signal when they have an answer. Keep all problems displayed throughout the talk. Follow with a whole-class discussion as needed to review the answers.


Student Activity

An exponent indicates repeated multiplication of the same quantity.

Expand each exponential expression to show repeated multiplication.

  1. \(4^3\) = ____________

    2. Answer: \(4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4\)

  2. \(x^5\) = ____________

    3. Answer: \(x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x\)

  3. \( (-8)^6\) = ____________

    4. Answer: \((-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8)\)

  4. \((-z)^3\) = ____________

    5. Answer: \((-z) \cdot (-z) \cdot (-z)\)

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share their answers as each expression is simplified into repeated multiplication. Then, discuss with students:

  • “What is the relationship between the base of the exponent and the factor used in the repeated multiplication expression?” (The base of the exponent is the same value or variable that is used in the repeated multiplication expression.)
  • “What is the relationship between the exponent value and the number of factors in the repeated multiplication expression?” (The exponent value will be equal to the number of factors in the repeated multiplication expression.)

page.title: 5.1.2: Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity prompts students to simplify expressions using the Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents. Students must understand that to multiply like bases, the exponents are added and to divide like bases, the exponents are subtracted. The base in these situations always remains the same.

Launch

Read the Product Property written in the middle column. Review the example provided as a class. If needed, complete one additional row in the table as a class.

Limit the time spent on the first table to 10 minutes and pause the class for questions before students move on to the second table.

Then have students complete the second table. Read the Quotient Property written in the middle column. Review the example provided as a class. If needed, complete one additional row in the table as a class.

Student Activity

  1. Complete the table using the Product Property for Exponents.

Product Property for Exponents

Expression

To multiply like bases, add the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(d^2 \cdot d^3\)

\(2 + 3\)

\(d^5\)

\(c^4 \cdot c^6\)

    

\(k^3 \cdot k^5\)

    

\((-v)^2 \cdot (-v)^1\)

    

\((m)^4 \cdot (m)^4\)

    

\((-p)^6 \cdot (-p)^3\)

    

Answer:

Product Property for Exponents

Expression

To multiply like bases, add the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(d^2 \cdot d^3\)

\(2 + 3\)

\(d^5\)

\(c^4 \cdot c^6\)

\(4 + 6\)

\(c^{10}\)

\(k^3 \cdot k^5\)

\(3 + 5\)

\(k^8\)

\((-v)^2 \cdot (-v)^1\)

\(2 + 1\)

\((-v)^3\)

\((m)^4 \cdot (m)^4\)

\(4 + 4\)

\(m^8\)

\((-p)^6 \cdot (-p)^8\)

\(6 + 8\)

\((-p)^{14}\)

  1. Complete the table using the Quotient Property for Exponents.

Quotient Property for Exponents

Expression

To divide like bases, subtract the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(\frac{y^5}{y^3}\)

\(5 – 3\)

\(y^2\)

\(\frac{r^4}{r}\)

    

\(\frac{q^9}{q^2}\)

    

\(\frac{(-u)^5}{(-u)^2}\)

    

\(\frac{(j)^6}{(j)^5}\)

    

\(\frac{(-z)^8}{(-z)^6}\)

    

Answer:

Quotient Property for Exponents

Expression

To divide like bases, subtract the exponents.

Simplified Result

\(\frac{y^5}{y^3}\)

\(5 – 3\)

\(y^2\)

\(\frac{r^4}{r}\)

\(4 – 1\)

\(r^3\)

\(\frac{q^9}{q^2}\)

\(9 – 2\)

\(q^7\)

\(\frac{(-u)^5}{(-u)^2}\)

\(5 – 2\)

\((-u)^3\)

\(\frac{(j)^6}{(j)^5}\)

\(6 – 5\)

\(j^1\)

\(\frac{(-z)^8}{(-z)^6}\)

\(8 – 6\)

\((-z)^2 = z^2\)

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to summarize the Product Property and Quotient Property for Exponents in their own words. Add any missing details as needed. Emphasize that when multiplying like bases, the exponents are added, when dividing like bases, the exponents are subtracted. Stress that the base in these situations always remains the same.

5.1.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Which of the following equations is correct?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(y^5 \cdot y^3=y^8\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: The expression uses the Product Property for Exponents. To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.

\(x^2 \cdot x^4=x^8\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The expression uses the Product Property for Exponents. To multiply with like bases, add the exponents, not multiply. The answer is \(y^5 \cdot y^3=y^8\).

\(\frac{y^6}{y^3}=y^2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation uses the Quotient Property for Exponents. To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents, not divide. The answer is \(y^5 \cdot y^3=y^8\).

\(\frac{(-u)^8}{(-u)^2}=2(-u)^4\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This equation uses the Quotient Property for Exponents. To divide with like bases, subtract the exponents, not divide. The answer is \(y^5 \cdot y^3=y^8\).

5.1.2: Additional Resources

Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents

When we combine like terms by adding and subtracting, we need to have the same base with the same exponent. But when you multiply and divide, the exponents may be different, and sometimes the bases may be different, too.

First, we will look at an example that leads to the Product Property.

What does \(x^2 \cdot x^3\) mean?


Notice that 5 is the sum of the exponents, 2 and 3. We see \(x^2 \cdot x^3\) is \(x^{2+3}\) or \(x^5\).

The base stayed the same, and we added the exponents. This leads to the Product Property for Exponents.


PRODUCT PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\(a^m \cdot a^n=a^{m+n}\)

To multiply with like bases, add the exponents.


Now we will look at an exponent property for division. As before, we’ll try to discover a property by looking at some examples.

  1. Consider \(\frac{x^5}{x^2}\)

Step 1
What does it mean? \(\frac{x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x}{x \cdot x}\)

Step 2
Use the Equivalent Fractions Property.
x   ·   x   ·   x   ·   x   ·   x x   ·   x

Step 3
Simplify.
\(x^3\)

  1. Consider \(\frac{x^2}{x^3}\)

Step 1
What does it mean?
\(\frac{x \cdot x}{x \cdot x \cdot x}\)

Step 2
Use the Equivalent Fractions Property.
x   ·   x   ·   1 x   ·   x   ·   x

Step 3
Simplify.
\(\frac1x\)

Notice that in each case, the bases were the same and we subtracted exponents. We see \(\frac{x^5}{x^2}\) is \(x^{5-2}\) or \(x^3\). We see \(\frac{x^2}{x^3}\) is \(\frac1x\). When the larger exponent was in the numerator, we were left with factors in the numerator. When the larger exponent was in the denominator, we were left with factors in the denominator—notice the numerator of 1. When all the factors in the numerator have been removed, remember this is really dividing the factors to one, so we need a 1 in the numerator. x x   = 1 . This leads to the Quotient Property for Exponents.


QUOTIENT PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number, \(a\neq0\), and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{m-n}\), \(m>n\) and \(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=\frac1{a^{n-m}}\), \(n>m\)


Try It: Using Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents

Simplify each expression.

  1. \( h^4 \cdot h^7\)
  2. \((-s)^2 \cdot (-s)^2\)
  3. \(\frac {b^7}{b^5}\)
  4. \({(-y)^6}{(-y)^3}\)
  5. \(\frac{x^3}{x^5}\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

Here is how to simplify the expressions:

  1. \(h^4 \cdot h^7= h^{11}\)
  2. \( (-s)^2(-s)^2=(-s)^4 \)
  3. \(\frac{b^7}{b^5} = b^2\)
  4. \(\frac{(-y)^6}{(-y)^3} = (-y)^3\)
  5. \(\frac{ x^3}{x^5}=\frac{1}{x^2}\)

Video: Understanding Product and Quotient Properties for Exponents

Watch the following video to learn more about applying the Product and Quotient Properties of Exponents.

page.title: 5.1.3: Using Zero Exponent Property and Negative Exponents
page.contents:
Activity (15 minutes)

This activity introduces how to simplify any expression with an exponent of 0. It also introduces the concept that a negative exponent is equivalent to the reciprocal of the expression while flipping the sign of the exponent.

As students complete the activity, monitor for those who:

  • try to reduce any value with an exponent of 0 to 0.
  • transfer a negative exponent to a negative sign in the base of the exponential expression.

Launch

Read the Zero Exponent Property written in the middle column. Stress that this is true for any value. If needed to reinforce this concept, complete the first row in the table as a class.

Limit the time spent on the first table to 5 minutes and pause the class for questions before students move on to the second table.

Then have students complete the second table. Read the definition of a negative exponent written in the middle column. Complete one row in the table as a class to reinforce comprehension.

The Zero Exponent Property is any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1, the simplified result to each expression is 1!


Student Activity

  1. Complete the table using the Zero Exponent Property.

Zero Exponent Property

Expression

Any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1.

Simplified Result

\(d^0\)

  

\(7^0\)

  

\((-8)^0\)

  

\((-v)^0\)

  

\(r^0 \cdot r^0\)

  

Answer:

Zero Exponent Property

Expression

Any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1.

Simplified Result

\(d^0\)

1

\(7^0\)

1

\((-8)^0\)

1

\((-v)^0\)

1

\(r^0 \cdot r^0\)

1

  1. Complete the table using the definition of a negative exponent.

Definition of a Negative Exponent

Expression

If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

Simplified Result

\(g^{-4}\)

  

\(2^{-3}\)

  

\(\frac{1}{c^{-2}}\)

  

\(\frac{1}{(-h)^{-6}}\)

  

\(\frac{1}{4^{-3}}\)

  

Answer:

Definition of a Negative Exponent

Expression

If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

Simplified Result

\(g^{-4}\)

\(\frac{1}{g^4}\)

\(2^{-3}\)

\(\frac{1}{2^3}\) or \(\frac18\)

\(\frac{1}{c^{-2}}\)

\(c^2\)

\(\frac{1}{(-h)^{-6}}\)

\((-h)^6\)

\(\frac{1}{4^{-3}}\)

\(4^3\) or \(64\)

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to summarize the Zero Exponent Property in their own words. Add any missing details as needed. Emphasize that any base raised to a power of 0 is always equal to 1. 

Ask students to summarize the definition of a negative exponent in their own words. Ask students how they would find an equivalent expression using non-negative exponents. If needed, revisit the rule written in the table.

5.1.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Which of the following equations is correct?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(8^0=0\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Any non-zero base raised to the power of zero equals 1. The answer is \(d^{-4}=\frac{1}{d^4}\).

\(w^{-6}=\frac{-6}{w^6}\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The –6 is an exponent, not a factor. Remember that \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\), so \(w^{-6}=\frac{1}{w^6}\). The answer is \(d^{-4}=\frac{1}{d^4}\).

\(7^{-3}=-343\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the result of finding the opposite of \(7^3\). Remember that \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\), so \(7^{-3}=\frac{1}{7^3}\). The answer is \(d^{-4}=\frac{1}{d^4}\).

\(d^{-4}=\frac{1}{d^4}\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Remember that \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

5.1.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Using the Zero Exponent Property

A special case of the Quotient Property is when the exponents of the numerator and denominator are equal, such as an expression like \(\frac{a^m}{a^m}\). We know \(\frac{x}{x}=1\) for any \(x\) (\(x\neq0\)) since any number divided by itself is 1. The Quotient Property for Exponents shows us how to simplify \(\frac{a^m}{a^m}\) when \(m>n\) and when \(n<m\) by subtracting exponents. What if \(m=n\)? We will simplify \(\frac{a^m}{a^m}\) in two ways to lead us to the definition of the Zero Exponent Property. In general, for \(a\neq0\):


ZERO EXPONENT PROPERTY

If \(a\) is a non-zero number, then \(a^0=1\).

If \(a\) is a non-zero number, then \(a\) to the power of zero equals 1.

Any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1.


Using the Definition of a Negative Exponent

We saw that the Quotient Property for Exponents has two forms depending on whether the exponent is larger in the numerator or the denominator. What if we just subtract exponents regardless of which is larger?

Let’s consider \(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\). We subtract the exponent in the denominator from the exponent in the numerator. We see \(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\) is \(x^{2-5}\) or \(x^{-3}\).

We can also simplify \(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\) by dividing out common factors:

\(\frac{x^2}{x^5}\)

x   ·   x x · x · x · x · x

\(\frac{1}{x^3}\)

This implies that \(x^{-3}=\frac{1}{x^3}\), and it leads us to the definition of a negative exponent. If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{-n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).

Let’s now look at what happens to a fraction whose numerator is one and whose denominator is an integer raised to a negative exponent.

\(\frac{1}{a^{−n}}\)

Step 1
Use the definition of a negative exponent, \(a^{−n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).
\(\frac{1}{\frac{1}{a^n}}\)

Step 2
Simplify the complex fraction.
\(1 \cdot \frac{a^n}{1}\)
\(\frac{x \cdot x}{x \cdot x \cdot x}\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(a^n\)


This implies \(\frac{1}{a^{-n}}=a^n\) and is another form of the definition of Properties of Negative Exponents.


PROPERTIES OF NEGATIVE EXPONENTS

If \(n\) is an integer and \(a\neq0\), then \(a^{−n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\) or \(\frac{1}{a^{−n}}=a^n\).


The negative exponent tells us we can rewrite the expression by taking the reciprocal of the base and then changing the sign of the exponent.

Any expression that has negative exponents is not considered to be in simplest form. We will use the definition of a negative exponent and other properties for exponents to write the expression with only positive exponents.

For example, if after simplifying an expression we end up with the expression \(x^{-3}\), we will take one more step and write \(\frac{1}{x^3}\). The answer is considered to be in simplest form when it has only positive exponents.

Try It: Using the Zero Exponent Property and Negative Exponents

Simplify each expression.

  1. \( h^0\)
  2. \(7^0\)
  3. \( (-g)^0\)
  4. \(a^{-4}\)
  5. \(9^{-3}\)
  6. \(\frac{1}{n^{-5}}\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to simplify the expressions:

  1. 1
  2. 1
  3. 1
  4. \(\frac{1}{a^4}\)
  5. \(\frac{1}{9^3}=\frac{1}{729}\)
  6. \(n^5\)

page.title: 5.1.4: Using Power Properties for Exponents
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity builds on strategies we used to simplify more complicated expressions involving exponents. Review the definition of a negative exponent before beginning the activity. If students seem stuck on any property, complete the first row of that table as a class.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of 2. Give students 3–5 minutes of quiet time per table to simplify as many expressions as they can. Then allow a minute to share their responses and strategies with their partner.


Student Activity

Work with a partner to complete the activity. Discuss any differences in the simplified results you find. Make sure you both understand each step you take to simplify.

  1. Complete the table using the Quotient to a Negative Power Property for exponents.

Quotient to a Negative Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(a\neq0\), \(b\neq0\), and \(n\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^{-n}=(\frac{b}{a})^n\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{3}{7})^{-5}\)

  

\((-\frac{y}{z})^{-7}\)

  

\((\frac{g}{h})^{-6}\)

  

Answer:

Quotient to a Negative Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(a\neq0\), \(b\neq0\), and \(n\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^{-n}=(\frac{b}{a})^n\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{3}{7})^{-5}\)

\((\frac{7}{3})^5 = (\frac{7^5}{3^5}) = \frac{16,807}{243}\)

\((-\frac{y}{z})^{-7}\)

\((-\frac{z}{y})^7 = -\frac{z^7}{y^7}\)

\((\frac{g}{h})^{-6}\)

\((\frac{h}{g})^6 =\frac{ h^6}{g^6}\)

  1. Complete the table using the Power Property for Exponents.

Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\)

Simplified Result

\((4^2)^5\)

  

\((n^3)^7\)

  

\((2^3)^2(d^4)^3\)

  

Answer:

Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\)

Simplified Result

\((4^2)^5\)

\(4^{10} = 1,048,576\)

\((n^3)^7\)

\(n^{21}\)

\((2^3)^2(d^4)^3\)

\((2^6)(d^{12}) = 64d^{12}\)

  1. Complete the table using the Product to a Power Property for exponents.

Product to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) is a whole number, then

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

Simplified Result

\((-2tv)^7\)

  

\((4pr^2)^5\)

  

\((3h^3)^{-2}\)

  

Answer:

Product to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) is a whole number, then

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

Simplified Result

\((-2tv)^7\)

\((-2)^7t^7v^7 = -128t^7v^7\)

\((4pr^2)^5\)

\(4^5p^5r^{10} = 1,024p^5r^{10}\)

\((3h^3)^{-2}\)

\((\frac{1}{3h^3})^2 = \frac{1}{3^2h^6} = \frac{1}{9h^6}\)

  1. Complete the table using the Quotient to a Power Property for exponents.

Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(b\neq0\), and \(m\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{j}{9})^3\)

  

\((\frac{5}{m})^2\)

  

\((\frac{y}{w})^{-5}\)

  

\((\frac{3ab^3}{c^2})^4\)

  

Answer:

Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents

Expression

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(b\neq0\), and \(m\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\)

Simplified Result

\((\frac{j}{9})^3\)

\(\frac{j^3}{9^3} = \frac{j^3}{729}\)

\((\frac{5}{m})^2\)

\((\frac{5}{m})^2=\frac{5^2}{m^2}=\frac{m^2}{25}\)

\((\frac{y}{w})^{-5}\)

\((\frac{w}{y})^5 = \frac{w^5}{y^5}\)

\((\frac{3ab^3}{c^2})^4\)

\(\frac{3^4a^4b^{12}}{c^8} =\frac {81a^4b^{12}}{c^8}\)

Activity Synthesis

Invite partners to share any example that gave them trouble. Solve the example as a class, discussing any tricky moments.

Discuss how the Quotient to a Negative Power Property is only one additional step before using the Quotient to a Power Property when simplifying. (That step is finding the reciprocal of the value and flipping the sign.)

5.1.4: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Simplify the following expression.

\((\frac{3^3x^{-2}}{q^3})^3\)

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(\frac{27}{x^2q^3}\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the simplified form of the expression without raising it to the power of 3. Remember to raise each factor in parentheses to the power of 3. Did you find \(3^9\)? Did you use the Power Property on \(x\) and \(q\)? The answer is \(\frac{19,683}{x^6q^9}\).

\(\frac{19,683}{x^6q^9}\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: We use the Power Property on each part. \(3^9 = 19,683\). The negative exponent on \(x\) moves it to the denominator where it becomes positive.

\(\frac{729}{x^6q^9}\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the value if you add the exponents when you raise \(3^3\) to the power of 3. Did you find \(3^9\)? The answer is \(\frac{19,683}{x^6q^9}\).  

\(\frac{19,683x^6}{q^9}\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you address the negative exponent on \(x\)? The answer is \(\frac{19,683}{x^6q^9}\). 

5.1.4: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Quotient to a Negative Power Property

Suppose now we have a fraction raised to a negative exponent. Let’s use our definition of negative exponents to lead us to a new property.


\((\frac34)^{−2}\)

Step 1
Use the definition of a negative exponent, \(a^{−n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\).
\(\frac{1}{(\frac{3}{4})^2}\)

Step 2
Simplify the denominator.
\(\frac1{\frac9{16}}\)

Step 3
Simplify the complex fraction.
\(\frac{16}{9}\)
But we know that \(\frac{16}{9}\) is \((\frac{4}{3})^2\).

Step 4
This tells us that
\((\frac{3}{4})^{−2}=(\frac{4}{3})^2\)


To get from the original fraction raised to a negative exponent to the final result, we took the reciprocal of the base—the fraction—and changed the sign of the exponent.

This leads us to the Quotient to a Negative Power Property.


QUOTIENT TO A NEGATIVE POWER PROPERTY

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(a\neq0\), \(b\neq0\), and \(n\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^{-n}=(\frac{b}{b})^n\)


Now that we have negative exponents, we can use the Product Property we learned in Activity 5.1.2 with expressions that have negative exponents, too.

Power Property for Exponents

Now let’s look at an exponential expression that contains a power raised to a power. See if you can discover a general property.

Notice the 6 is the product of the exponents, 2 and 3. We see that \((x^2)^3\) is \(x^{2 \cdot 3}\) or \(x^6\).

We multiplied the exponents. This leads to the Power Property for Exponents.


POWER PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) is a real number and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\)

To raise a power to a power, multiply the exponents.


Product to a Power Property for Exponents

We will now look at an expression containing a product that is raised to a power. Can you find this pattern?

\((2x)^3\)


Step 1
What does this mean?
\(2x \cdot 2x \cdot 2x \)

Step 2
We group the like factors together.
\(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x\)

Step 3
How many factors of 2 and of \(x\)?
\(2^3 \cdot x^3\)


Notice that each factor was raised to the power and \((2x)^3\) is \(2^3 \cdot x^3\).

The exponent applies to each of the factors. This leads to the Product to a Power Property for Exponents.


PRODUCT TO A POWER PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) is a whole number, then

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

To raise a product to a power, raise each factor to that power.


Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents

Now we will look at an example that will lead us to the Quotient to a Power Property.


\((\frac{x}{y})^3\)

Step 1
This means
\(\frac{x}{y} \cdot \frac{x}{y} \cdot \frac{x}{y}\)

Step 2
Multiply the fractions.
\(\frac{x \cdot x \cdot x}{y \cdot y \cdot y}\)

Step 3
Write with exponents.
\(\frac{x^3}{y^3}\)


Notice that the exponent applies to both the numerator and the denominator.

We see that \((\frac{x}{y})^3\) is \(\frac{x^3}{y^3}\).

This leads to the Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents.


QUOTIENT TO A POWER PROPERTY FOR EXPONENTS

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers, \(b\neq0\), and \(m\) is an integer, then

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\)

To raise a fraction to a power, raise the numerator and denominator to that power.


Try It: Using Power Properties for Exponents

Simplify each expression using the property identified.

Use the Quotient to a Negative Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \( (\frac{3}{7})^{-5}\)
  2. \(( -\frac{r}{s})^{-2}\)

Use the Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \((x^3)^5\)
  2. \((2^2)^3\)
  3. \((h^4)^5(h^2)^2\)

Use the Product to a Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \((-2cd)^6\)
  2. \( (4z)^{-3}\)

Use the Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents.

  1. \((\frac{ 2xy^2}{z})^3\)
  1. \((\frac{4p^{-3}}{q^2})^2 \)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to simplify the expressions:

  1. \( (\frac{3}{7})^{-5} = (\frac{7}{3})^5= \frac{7^5}{3^5} = \frac{16,807}{243}\)
  1. \((-\frac{r}{s})^{-2} = (-\frac{s}{r})^2= \frac{s^2}{r^2}\)
  1. \((x^3)^5 = x^{15}\)
  1. \( (2^2)^3 = 2^6 = 64\)
  1. \( (h^4)^5(h^2)^2 = (h^{20})(h^4) = h^{24}\)
  1. \((-2cd)^6 = (-2)^6c^6d^6 = 64c^6d^6\)
  1. \((4z)^{-3} = \frac{1}{(4z)^3} = \frac{1}{4^3z^3} =\frac{1}{64z^3}\)
  1. \((\frac{2xy^2}{z})^3\)

    2. Step 1
    Use Quotient to a Power Property, \((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\).
    \(\frac{(2xy^2)^3}{z^3}\)

    Step 2
    Use the Product to a Power Property, \((ab)^m=a^mb^m\).
    \(\frac{8x^3y^6}{z^3}\)

  1. \((\frac{4p^{−3}}{q^2})^2\)

    2. Step 1
    Use Quotient to a Power Property, \((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\).
    \(\frac{(4p^{−3})^2}{(q^2)^2}\)

    Step 2
    Use the Product to a Power Property,\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\).
    \(\frac{4^2(p^{−3})^2}{(q^2)^2}\)

    Step 3
    Simplify using the Power Property,\((a^m)^n=a^{m \cdot n}\).
    \(\frac{16p^{−6}}{q^4}\)

    Step 4
    Use the definition of negative exponent.
    \(\frac{16}{q^4} \cdot \frac{1}{p^6}\)

    Step 5
    Simplify.
    \(\frac{16}{p^6q^4}\)

page.title: 5.1.5: Simplifying Exponents
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Complete the table using all of the exponent properties you learned in the lesson.

Exponent Property Review

Expression

Simplified Result

\(j^5 \cdot j^3\)

\(\frac{h^7}{h^3}\)

\((-ab)^0\)

\(\frac{1}{s^{-4}}\)

\((\frac{m}{n})^{-4}\)

\((p^5)^2\)

\((3s^3t^2)^3\)

\((\frac{b}{d})^{-2}\)

Answer:

Exponent Property Review

Expression

Simplified Result

\(j^5 \cdot j^3\)

\(j^8\)

\(\frac{h^7}{h^3}\)

\(h^4\)

\((-ab)^0\)

\(1\)

\(\frac{1}{s^{-4}}\)

\(s^4\)

\((\frac{m}{n})^{-4}\)

\(\frac{n^4}{m^4}\)

\((p^5)^2\)

\(p^{10}\)

\((3s^3t^2)^3\)

\(3^3s^9t^6 = 27s^9t^6\)

\((\frac{b}{d})^{-2}\)

\(\frac{d^2}{b^2}\)

Take some time to review each of the exponential properties you learned in the lesson. Look at each property and be sure you know when to use it.


SUMMARY OF EXPONENT PROPERTIES

If \(a\) and \(b\) are real numbers and \(m\) and \(n\) are integers, then

Property

Description

Product Property

\(a^m \cdot a^n={a^{m+n}}\)

Power Property

\((a^m)^n=a^{m·n}\)

Product to a Power

\((ab)^m=a^mb^m\)

Quotient Property

\(\frac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{m−n}\), \(a\neq0\)

Zero Exponent Property

\(a^0=1\), \(a\neq0\)

Quotient to a Power Property

\((\frac{a}{b})^m=\frac{a^m}{b^m}\), \(b\neq0\)

Properties of Negative Exponents

\(a^{−n}=\frac{1}{a^n}\) and \(\frac{1}{a^{−n}}=a^n\)

Quotient to a Negative Exponent

\((\frac{a}{b})^{−n}=(\frac{b}{a})^n\)

page.title: 5.1.6: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

Simplify each expression using the appropriate property from the lesson.

  1. \(f^2 \cdot f^6\)
    1. \(f^{36}\)
    2. \(f^4\)
    3. \(f^{12}\)
    4. \(f^8\)

ANSWER: d. \(f^8\)

  1. \(\frac{(-y)^6}{(-y)^3}\)
    1. \((-y)^3\)
    2. \((-y)^2\)
    3. \((-y)^9\)
    4. \((-y)^{18}\)

ANSWER:  a. \((-y)^3\)

  1. \((-4)^0\)
    1. \(0\)
    2. \(4\)
    3. \(1\)
    4. \(-4\)

ANSWER: c. \(1\)

  1. \(2^{-3}\)
    1. \( 8\)
    2. \(-6 \)
    3. \(\frac18\)
    4. \( -\frac18 \)

ANSWER: c. \(\frac18\)

  1. \(\frac{1}{(-t)^{-5}}\)
    1. \( t^4\)
    2. \(t^5\)
    3. \(\frac{1}{t^5}\)
    4. \((-t)^5\)

ANSWER: d. \((-t)^5\)

  1. \((-\frac{m}{n})^{-3}\)
    1. \(\frac{n^3}{m^3} \)
    2. \(\frac{m^3}{n^3}\)
    3. \(-\frac{n^3}{m^3}\)
    4. \( -\frac{m^3}{n^3}\)

ANSWER: c. \(-\frac{n^3}{m^3}\)

  1. \((d^3)^5\)
    1. \( d^{15}\)
    2. \(d^8\)
    3. \(d^5 \)
    4. \(d^{-2}\)

ANSWER: a. \( d^{15}\)

  1. \(( 5x^{-2})^3\)
    1. \(\frac{ 125}{x^5}\)
    2. \(5x\)
    3. \(\frac{125}{x^6}\)
    4. \(125x\)

ANSWER: c. \(\frac{125}{x^6}\)

  1. \((\frac{7b^3c}{d^2})^2\)
    1. \(\frac{d^4}{49b^6c^2}\)
    2. \(\frac{7b^6c^2}{d^4}\)
    3. \(\frac{49b^6c^2}{d^4}\)
    4. \(\frac{49b^5c^2}{d^4}\)

ANSWER: c. \(\frac{49b^6c^2}{d^4}\)

  1. \((\frac{3z^{-2}}{w^2})^{-2}\)
    1. \(9z^4w^4\)
    2. \(\frac{9w^4}{z^4}\)
    3. \(\frac{w^4}{9z^4}\)
    4. \(\frac{z^4w^4}{9}\)

ANSWER: d. \(\frac{z^4w^4}{9}\)

page.title: 5.1.7: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
Some key takeaways from this lesson are the properties used to simplify the different exponential expressions.

To help students see remember these properties, review the following points:

  • Exponential expressions can be represented using repeated multiplication.
  • The Product Property for Exponents is used when you are multiplying exponential terms with the same base. To simplify, the exponential terms are added and the same base is kept.
  • The Quotient Property for Exponents is used when you are dividing exponential terms with the same base. To simplify, the exponential terms are subtracted and the same base is kept.
  • The Zero Exponent Property states that any non-zero number raised to the zero power is 1.
  • The Properties of Negative Exponents state that when simplifying a term with a negative exponent, the reciprocal of the base is used and the sign of the exponent is flipped.
  • The Quotient to a Negative Power Property is used to simplify values being divided while all raised to a negative exponent. First, the expression is rewritten using the Properties of Negative Exponents to find its equivalent using non-negative exponents. Then the exponent is distributed to the dividend and the divisor so that each is raised to the same power.
  • The Power Property for Exponents states that to simplify an expression with equivalent bases in which a power is raised to a power, the exponents are multiplied.
  • The Product to a Power Property for Exponents states that when you raise products to a power, all factors being multiplied are raised to that power.
  • The Quotient to a Power Property for Exponents states that when you raise a divisor and dividend to a power, both are raised to that power.

If needed, review the chart in the last activity as a class to review the rules.
